questions.question: A mother reports to the OPD with the complaint that her child smells funny. On examination,you notice that the child has a global developmental delay and smells mousy. What is yourprobable diagnosis?

A boy who attends school is sent to the principal's office as he often distracts others byrhythmically rocking back and forth on his seat. His mother worried about his behaviorbrings him to you. She also gives you a history of seizures. On examination, you notice he hasblonde hair, fair skin, microcephaly, prominent maxillae with widely spaced teeth, andgrowth retardation. His urine changes its color transiently to blue-green on the addition of1ml ferric chloride solution. What is the cause of CNS symptoms in this child?
questions.explanation: The clinical vignette describes a case of phenylketonuria. CNS damage in patients withphenylketonuria (PKU) is caused by hyperphenylalaninemia in brain tissue.High blood levels of phenylalanine saturate the transport system across the blood-brain barriercausing inhibition of the cerebral uptake of other large neutral amino acids such as tyrosine andtryptophan impairing brain protein synthesis.Microcephaly, prominent maxillae with widely spaced teeth, enamel hypoplasia, and growthretardation are other common findings in untreated children. Low bone mineral density andosteopenia have been reported in affected individuals of all ages.Excess phenylalanine is metabolized to phenyl ketones (phenylpyruvate and phenylacetate) thatare excreted in the urine. However, these metabolites have no role in the pathogenesis of CNSdamage; their presence in body fluids simply signifies the severity of the condition.247Hypotyrosinemia can be partially responsible for the signs and symptoms but the primary cause ishyperphenylalaninemia.Laboratory diagnoses of phenylketonuria include:• Guthrie's test: growth of bacillus subtilis is seen• Ferric chloride urine test: transient blue-green color• Blood phenylalanine levels: elevated.•• Enzyme studies• Genetic mutation studies• Tandem mass spectrometry: Gold standard screening method for all metabolic disorders.

questions.question: An infant with severe vomiting who was misdiagnosed as a case of hypertrophic pyloricstenosis is being screened for metabolic disorders. Screening reveals hyperphenylalaninemia.On ordering an enzyme study, you would include all of the following enzymes except:
questions.explanation: Defects of either phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH) or tetrahydrobiopterin(BH4) can causehyperphenylalaninemias.PAH deficiency is diagnosed as phenylketonuria.Malignant hyperphenylalaninemias include three enzyme defects, dihydropteridinereductase, pyruvoyl tetrahydropterin synthase, and GTP cyclohydrolase which help in BH4synthesis. The deficiency of BH4 impairs three hydroxylase (phenylalanine, tyrosine, andtryptophan), and severe neurological symptoms develop because of the lack of neurotransmitters.Dihydropteroate synthase is present only in bacteria and this makes it a useful target forsulfonamide antibiotics, which compete with the PABA precursor.

questions.question: As a physician treating a 2-month-old baby with phenylketonuria what will be your mainstayof treatment?
questions.explanation: A low-phenylalanine diet is the mainstay of treatment of PKU.The goal of therapy is to reduce phenylalanine levels in the plasma and brain. Becausephenylalanine is not synthesized endogenously, small amounts of phenylalanine should be addedto the diet to prevent phenylalanine deficiency. Dietary deficiency of this amino acid is manifestedby lethargy, failure to thrive, anorexia, anemia, rashes, diarrhea, and even death; moreover,tyrosine becomes an essential amino acid in this disorder and its adequate intake must beensured.Sapropterin dihydrochloride, a synthetic form of BH4, which acts as a cofactor in patients withresidual PAH activity, is approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) to reducephenylalanine levels in PKU.

questions.question: An infant born out of a second-degree consanguineous marriage presents with jaundice,irritability, and vomiting. His mother gives a history of fever for the past 4 days. Onexamination, petechiae are present, he has hepatomegaly and extensor hypertonia of the neckand trunk. Labs reveal elevated serum transaminases, hypophosphatemia, and elevated levelsof succinylacetone in serum and urine. Which of the following enzymes is deficient?
questions.explanation: 248The clinical vignette describes a case of Hereditary tyrosinemia type 1 is caused by the deficiencyof fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase (FAAH).Elevated levels of succinylacetone in serum and urine are diagnostic for tyrosinemia type I.Liver (jaundice, acute hepatic crisis, elevated serum transaminases), kidney(hypophosphatemia),and nerve damage(extensor hypertonia of neck and trunk) are caused by metabolites of tyrosinedegradation, especially fumarylacetoacetate and succinylacetone, and is usually precipitated byminor infections.A diet low in phenylalanine and tyrosine can slow but does not halt the progression of thecondition. The treatment of choice is nitisinone (NTBC), which inhibits 4-HPPD and reduces theflux of tyrosine metabolites to FAH, thus decreasing the production of the offending compounds,fumarylacetoacetate, and succinylacetone.Tyrosine MetabolismTyrosinetransaminaseL-Tyrosinea-KGPLPGlup-Hydroxyphenylpyruvate[Q]p-HydroxyphenylpyruvatehydroxylaseCO2Homogentisate[O]HomogentisateoxidaseFe2+MaleylacetoacetateMaleylacetoacetateCis, trans isomeraseGlutathioneFumarylacetoacetateH₂OFumarateB-KetothiolasetAcetoacetaterAcetyl-CoACOASHAcetateOMARROW

questions.question: A father while changing his child's diaper observes a boiled cabbage odor emanating from it.Curious about the smell, he calls you. As a pediatrician, you investigate the child thoroughlyand conclude that the child is suffering from Type 1 Tyrosinemia. As the child grows all of thefollowing complications can occur except:
questions.explanation: Corneal ulceration is not a feature of hereditary tyrosinemia type 1. In fact, ocular manifestationsare a feature of hereditary tyrosinemia type 2 which presumably occur due to tyrosine deposition.Boiled cabbage odor may be present in tyrosinemia resulting from increased methioninemetabolites (sulfur-containing compounds).Features of hereditary tyrosinemia type 1 (hepatorenal tyrosinemia):• An acute hepatic crisis commonly heralds the onset of disease, which may progress to liverfailure, hepatocellular carcinoma, and death.•Episodes of acute peripheral neuropathy resembling porphyrias often triggered by a minorinfection, such crisis can be associated with paralytic ileus•Renal involvement, which is manifested as a Fanconi-like syndrome with hyperphosphaturia,hypophosphatemia, normal anion gap metabolic acidosis, and vitamin D-resistant rickets249The treatment of choice for HT Type 1 is nitisinone, which blocks early steps in the tyrosinedegradation pathway and limits the formation of toxic tyrosine metabolites.Note:Boiled cabbage odor can also be found in cases of Hypermethioninemia.

questions.question: 239A 2-year-old girl presented with photophobia and speech delay. On examination, she hadbilateral herpetiform corneal ulcers and painful hyperkeratotic plaques on the palms andsoles. Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Palmar and plantar hyperkeratosis, herpetiform corneal ulcers, and intellectual disability are seenin hereditary tyrosinemia type 2 (Richner-Hanhart syndrome/ oculocutaneous tyrosinemia)Treatment with a diet low in tyrosine and phenylalanine aiming to achieve plasma tyrosine levels<500 μmol/L improves skin and eye manifestations.The image below shows herpetiform corneal ulcer:

questions.question: A child who was being evaluated for hypertyrosinemia is diagnosed with Richner-Hanhartsyndrome. Which of the following enzyme deficiencies is the likely cause of hypertyrosinemiain this patient?
questions.explanation: Oculocutaneous tyrosinemia/Richner-Hanhart syndrome (type II) is caused by the deficiency oftyrosine aminotransferase.It is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by palmar and plantar hyperkeratosis,herpetiform corneal ulcers, and intellectual disability. Untreated patients havemarked hypertyrosinemia. In contrast to tyrosinemia type I, liver and kidney function are normal,as are serum concentrations of other amino acids and succinylacetone.250Tyrosine MetabolismTyrosinetransaminaseL-Tyrosinea-KGPLPGlup-Hydroxyphenylpyruvatep-Hydroxyphenylpyruvatehydroxylase[O]CO2HomogentisateHomogentisateoxidase[O]FOR+MaleylacetoacetateMaleylacetoacetateGlutathioneCis, trans isomeraseFumarylacetoacetateH₂OFumarateB-KetothiolaseAcetoacetaterAcetyl-CoAAcetateCOASHMARROW

questions.question: A 15-month-old baby who presented with seizures and self-injurious behavior has increasedplasma tyrosine levels. Urine metabolic screening reveals the presence of4-hydroxyphenylpyruvic acid and its metabolites 4-hydroxyphenyllactic and 4-hydroxyphenylacetic acids. Which of the following in-born errors of metabolism is the child suffering from?
questions.explanation: Primary deficiency of 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvate dioxygenase (4-HPPD) causes hereditarytyrosinemia type 3. The diagnosis is suspected in children with sustained moderate increases inplasma levels of tyrosine (typically 350-700 μmol/L on a normal diet) and the presence of4-hydroxyphenylpyruvic acid and its metabolites 4-hydroxyphenyllactic and4-hydroxyphenylacetic acids in urine.Asymptomatic infants with 4-HPPD deficiency have been identified by neonatal screening forhypertyrosinemia. In symptomatic patients, developmental delay, seizures, intermittent ataxia,and self-injurious behavior have been reported. Liver and renal abnormalities are absent.Note:Transient tyrosinemia of the newborn is the most common acquired cause for increased plasmatyrosine levels. Seen in premature infants receiving a high protein diet and due to the immaturityof 4-HPPD enzyme. Mostly asymptomatic, but sometimes manifested by lethargy, poor feeding,and decreased motor activity. Hypertyrosinemia usually resolvesspontaneously in the first 2 months of life. Treatment includes a low protein diet and vitamin C.251Tyrosine MetabolismTyrosinetransaminaseL-Tyrosinea-KGPLPGlup-Hydroxyphenylpyruvatep-Hydroxyphenylpyruvatehydroxylase[O]CO2HomogentisateHomogentisateoxidase[O]FOR+MaleylacetoacetateMaleylacetoacetateGlutathioneCis, trans isomeraseFumarylacetoacetateH₂OFumarateB-KetothiolaseAcetoacetaterAcetyl-CoAAcetateCOASHMARROW

questions.question: A 4-month-old infant who was started on a high-protein diet after weaning frombreastfeeding developed severe metabolic acidosis, ketosis, failure to thrive, mildhepatomegaly, and an unusual swimming pool odor. A history of similar illness was noticedin his siblings and his father. What is the likely diagnosis?240
questions.explanation: The clinical vignette and the characteristic swimming pool odor describe Hawkinsinuria.Hawkinsinuria is an autosomal-dominant condition caused by mutations in the gene for 4-HPPD.In infants, this disease causes severe metabolic acidosis, ketosis, failure to thrive, mildhepatomegaly, and swimming pool odor. Mental development is usually normal. Affectedindividuals excrete hawkinsin (4-hydroxyphenylpyruvic acid), and its metabolites.Treatment consists of a low-protein diet during infancy. Breastfeeding is encouraged. A trial withlarge doses of vitamin C (up to 1,000 mg/24 hour) is also recommended.

questions.question: The following findings in an 18-year-old are characterized by a deficiency of
questions.explanation: The following condition is characterized by the deficiency of homogentisic acid oxidase.The image represents ochronosis: Bluish-black pigmentation of the ear cartilage and/or sclera dueto deposits of accumulated homogentisic acid.This is characteristically seen in alkaptonuria. It is a rare autosomal-recessive disorder is causedby the deficiency of homogentisic acid oxidase. Large amounts of homogentisic acid are formed,which are excreted in urine or deposited in tissues. Clinical manifestations of alkaptonuria consistof ochronosis and arthritis in adulthood. Arthritis predominantly involves the spine, hip, andknee. Radiologically, it is characterized by intervertebral calcifications. In children, blackening ofthe urine on standing is observed; it is caused by the oxidation and polymerization ofhomogentisic acid.252

questions.question: A patient presented to the OPD with complaints of pigmentation of the face and severebackache and stiffness. The X-Ray image of the spine is as shown. Her urine color changes tobrownish-black on standing. Which of the following drugs can be used in her treatment?241
questions.explanation: The clinical image shows the accumulation of alkapton bodies in connective tissues on the faceand urine turning brownish-black on standing are associatedwith alkaptonuria. X-ray shows calcification of intervertebral discs called ochronoticspondyloarthropathy also seen in alkaptonuria. Nitisinone can be used in the treatment ofalkaptonuria.Nitisinone, formerly known as NTBC, inhibits 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvate dioxygenase (HPPD)(early step in the tyrosine degradation pathway) and efficiently reduces homogentisic acidproduction in alkaptonuria. Treatment of arthritis is symptomatic. In presymptomatic individuals,treatment using a combination of nitisinone with phenylalanine and a tyrosine restricted diet canbe tried.The patient's urine contains elevated levels of homogentisic acid, which is oxidized to a darkpigment on standing as shown below in the image:

questions.question: A 10-year-old boy presented with right-sided weakness and deviation of angle of mouth to theleft is diagnosed to have a metabolic disorder. Diffusion-weighted MRI reveals diffusionrestriction along the left middle cerebral artery. Which of the following defects can beresponsible for the boy's condition?
questions.explanation: The clinical vignette describes a thrombotic stroke in the left MCA territory. Elevated levels ofserum homocysteine lead to a hypercoagulable state.•Homocystinuria is caused by the following:Cystathionine ẞ-Synthase deficiency: This is classic homocystinuria. The most common inbornerror of methionine metabolism.⚫ Defects in methylcobalamin formation: Methylcobalamin is the cofactor for the enzymemethionine synthase, which catalyzes the remethylation of homocysteine to methionine.• Deficiency of methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase: This enzyme reduces 5,10methylenetetrahydrofolate to form 5-methyltetrahydrofolate, which provides the methyl groupneeded for remethylation of homocysteine to methionine.253• Pyridoxine deficiency: B6 is the co-factor for the enzyme cystathionine ẞ-synthaseFolateCauses of homocystinuriaDietary proteinsTetrahydrofolate5.10-MethylenetetrahydrofolateMethylenetetrahydrofolate reductaseMethionineTransmethylationMethioninesynthaseVitamin B5-MethylenetetrahydrofolateMADimethylglycine.Betaine-homocysteinemethyltransferaseHomocysteinet +BetaineCystathioninep-synthase+Vitamin B₁LCystathionineCysteineOMARROWWMetabolic disorders which can cause stroke include:• Homocystinuria•MELAS (metabolic encephalopathy, lactic acidosis, and stroke-like episodes)• Leigh syndrome•Fabry's disease•Propionic acidemia•Glutaric aciduriaVitamin C deficiency increases the risk of hemorrhagic stroke.

questions.question: An 8-month-old boy presented with lethargy, failure to thrive, and developmental delay. Oninvestigation, he had elevated levels of homocysteine in blood and homocystinuria. As thechild grows, which of the following features is least likely to develop?
questions.explanation: The above findings support a diagnosis of homocystinuria. Short stature is not a manifestation ofhomocystinuria.Manifestations of homocystinuria:•Ectopia lentis - downward and inward subluxation (inferonasal).• Intellectual disability and psychiatric and behavioral disorders•⚫ Thromboembolic episodes like stroke and MI• Skeletal abnormalities resembling those of Marfan syndrome: They are tall and thin, (NOT short)with elongated limbs and arachnodactyly.

questions.question: A 16-year-old boy with frequent episodes of photosensitive dermatitis, diarrhea, anddepression is diagnosed to have a metabolic disorder. Metabolism of which of the followingamino acids is affected?
questions.explanation: 254Pellagra-like symptoms- photosensitive dermatitis, diarrhea, and episodic depression are seen inthe deficiency of tryptophan.Niacin is not strictly a vitamin, since it can be synthesized in the body from the essential aminoacid tryptophan; deficiency of tryptophan causes pellagra-like symptoms.Treatment with nicotinic acid or nicotinamide (50-300 mg/24 hr) and a high protein diet resultsin a favorable response in symptomatic patients with Hartnup disease.The image below shows Casal's necklace, a lesion seen around the neck which is caused due to thedeficiency of niacin or nicotinic acid.Casal's paint necklace in Pellagra

questions.question: Which of the following is false regarding Hartnup disease?

options.A: Defect in the transport of monoamino-monocarboxylic amino acids, including tryptophan, isseen
options.B: Defect in the BOAT1 protein occurs in the intestine and renal tubules
options.C: Pellagra-like rash may develop in symptomatic patients
options.D: Treatment is with supplementation of tryptophan

questions.explanation: The treatment of Hartnup disease is not with the supplementation of tryptophan.Hartnup disease• It is caused by a defect in the transport of monoamino-monocarboxylic (neutral) amino acids,including tryptophan, by the intestinal mucosa and renal tubules.•There is a defect in BOAT1 protein in the intestine/ renal tubules or both, which is caused by amutation in SLC6A19.•Tryptophan is an essential amino acid and a precursor for nicotinic acid (niacin) and serotonin.Decreased intestinal absorption of tryptophan in conjunction with its increased renal loss causesreduced availability of tryptophan for niacin synthesis in affected individuals.• A pellagra-like rash may develop in symptomatic patients, and some patients may haveintermittent ataxia.• Diagnosis is based on aminoaciduria and increased excretion of indole compounds detectedby Obermeyer test.• Treatment is with nicotinic acid or nicotinamide and a high-protein diet.255

questions.question: An infant with poor feeding is suspected to have an inborn error of metabolism. Furtherevaluation reveals hyperammonemia +, acidosis +, ketosis +. What is the most likelydiagnosis?
questions.explanation: In this case, hyperammonemia +, acidosis +, ketosis +. This is seen in organic aciduria.Organic acidemias most commonly present in infancy with poor feeding, vomiting, hypotonia,high anion gap metabolic acidosis, hepatomegaly, seizures. Organic acid accumulation inhibitsgluconeogenesis and inhibits the urea cycle leading to hyperammonemia.Common organic acidurias:••Methylmalonic aciduriaPropionic aciduria• Isovaleric aciduria•Maple syrup urine disease• Glutaric aciduria type I• Multiple carboxylase deficiencyInitial clinical approach to a full-term newborninfant with a suspected geneticmetabolic disorderLInitial findings include one or more of the following:a) Poor feedingb) Vomiting (not due to GI anomalies)c) Lethargyd) Convulsione) ComaNot responsive tointravenous glucose, calcium or vitamin BeMetabolic disorderMHighObtainplasma ammoniaObtainblood pH, CO,. HCO-Normal aniongapInfection, trauma,CNS anomalieswNormalObtainblood pH. CO. HCOHigh aniongapAcidosisUres cycledefectsOrganicacidemiasOMARROWNormal aniongapAminoacidopathies.or galactosemia

questions.question: 243A 10-day-old male infant presented with poor feeding, and recurrent generalized convulsions.On examination, the pediatrician notices repetitive movements of the extremities -appears tobe boxing and bicycling and a peculiar burnt sugar odor was present in urine. What is thedeficient enzyme in this condition?
questions.explanation: The diagnosis is maple syrup urine disease (MSUD) which is due to deficiency of branched-chaina-ketoacid dehydrogenase (BCKDH).Leucine, isoleucine, and valine are the 3 essential amino acids, which are branched-chain aminoacids. Their decarboxylation is accomplished by BCKDH using thiamine (vitamin B1)pyrophosphate as a coenzyme.Leucine is metabolized by BCAA aminotransferase to α-ketoisocaproic acid, which leads to thedisrupted metabolism of neurotransmitters and amino acids (glutamate, GABA, glutamine,256alanine, and aspartate). α-Ketoisocaproic acid can reversibly inhibit oxidative phosphorylationand result in cerebral lactic acidosis. Collectively, these processes are detrimental to the normalfunction of neurons and glia, clinically manifesting as encephalopathy and brain edema andreferred to as leucinosis.Treatment options include hemodialysis, restricting dietary substances, thiamine for milderforms, and orthotopic liver transplant.

questions.question: While doing your morning rounds in the pediatrics department, you notice a peculiar rancidcheese odor emanating from a six-month-old girl who was admitted for respiratory distress.Second-degree consanguinity was documented between the parents. Urine organic acidanalysis by gas chromatography-mass spectrometry showed marked excretion of3-hydroxybutyric acid along with moderate excretion of 3-hydroxy-isovaleric acid. What isthe most likely condition is she suffering from?
questions.explanation: The clinical vignette suggests a diagnosis of isovaleric acidemia. Sweaty-feet odor or rancid cheeseodor may be present.Isovaleric acidemia is caused by the deficiency of the enzyme isovaleryl CoA dehydrogenase,which affects the breakdown pathway of leucine leading to the accumulation of intermediates.

questions.question: A mother brings her 3-year-old boy with the complaints that her child's urine smells like hertomcat's urine. She also gives a history of generalized seizures and perioral desquamatinglesions. On examination, the child has global developmental delay and diffuse thinning of thescalp. Investigations reveal multiple carboxylase deficiency. What is the treatment of choice?
questions.explanation: Biotin is the treatment of choice for multiple carboxylase deficiency.Multiple carboxylase deficiency refers to one of two inherited defects of biotin metabolism.Tomcat urine is characteristically seen in multiple carboxylase deficiency.•Neonatal/infantile form is caused by a deficiency of holocarboxylase synthetase and presents inthe first week of life with lethargy, poor muscle tone, and vomiting.•⚫ Juvenile/late form is caused by biotinidase deficiency and is associated with a slow butprogressive loss of biotin in the urine, leading to organic aciduria. It is characterized by alopecia,ataxia, ketoacidosis, dermatitis, seizures, myoclonus, and nystagmus.Both infantile and late-onset multiple carboxylase deficiency can be treated with pharmacologicaldoses of biotin.It is called multiple carboxylase deficiency because biotin is a water-soluble vitamin that is acofactor for all 4 carboxylase enzymes in humans:• Pyruvate carboxylase• Acetyl CoA carboxylase• Propionyl CoA carboxylase• 3-methylcrotonyl CoA carboxylaseNote:Acquired deficiency of biotin may occur in infants receiving total parenteral nutrition withoutadded biotin, in patients with prolonged use of antiepileptic drugs (phenobarbital, phenytoin,primidone, carbamazepine), and in children with short bowel syndrome or chronic diarrhea whoare receiving formulas low in biotin. Excessive ingestion of raw eggs may also cause biotindeficiency because the protein avidin in egg white binds biotin, decreasing its absorption. Infantswith a biotin deficiency may develop dermatitis, alopecia, and candidal skin infections. This257condition readily responds to treatment with oral biotin.

questions.question: 244Which of the following is the most common acquired cause of increased plasma tyrosinelevels?
questions.explanation: Transient tyrosinemia of the newborn is the most common acquired cause for increased plasmatyrosine levels. Seen in premature infants receiving a high protein diet and due to the immaturityof 4-HPPD enzyme. Mostly asymptomatic, but sometimes manifested by lethargy, poor feeding,and decreased motor activity. Treatment includes low protein diet and vitamin C.Options A and B, i.e., hepatorenal tyrosinemia and oculocutaneous tyrosinemia, are hereditarycauses of increased tyrosine levels.Option C: Tyrosine levels are normal in alkaptonuria.

questions.question: Richner-Hanhart syndrome is
questions.explanation: Richner-Hanhart syndrome is hereditary tyrosinemia type 2 (oculocutaneous tyrosinemia).••It is a rare autosomal-recessive disorder is caused by the deficiency of tyrosine aminotransferase.It is characterized by ocular manifestations, skin lesions, and mild to moderate intellectualdisability in ~50% of the patients.•It is diagnosed by an assay of plasma tyrosine concentration.• Treatment includes a diet low in tyrosine and phenylalanine.

questions.question: In phenylketonuria, which of the following phenyl ketones is excreted in urine?
questions.explanation: In phenylketonuria, phenylpyruvate is excreted in the urine.In phenylketonuria (PKU), excess phenylalanine in the blood is metabolized to phenyl ketones,namely, phenylpyruvate and phenylacetate, which are excreted in the urine, giving rise to the termphenylketonuria (PKU).Acetoacetate and beta-hydroxybutyrate are keto-acids but are not phenyl ketones. These are notexcreted in phenylketonuria.

questions.question: A 2-month-old infant presented with abdominal distention and increased irritability for 10days. Physical examination showed jaundice, hepatomegaly, and a boiled cabbage odor.Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The clinical vignette is in favor of tyrosinemia. Boiled cabbage odor may be present in tyrosinemiaresulting from increased methionine metabolites (sulfur-containing compounds).Note:Boiled cabbage odor can also be found in cases of Hypermethioninemia.258

questions.question: A neonate born out of a second-degree consanguineous marriage is suspected to have aninborn error of metabolism. He can present with all of the following except:
questions.explanation: Irritability and incessant crying are not classical features of inborn errors of metabolism (IEM).Clinical clues suggesting IEM in a neonate are:• Unexpected deterioration after a normal initial period.•Nonspecific, unexplained features such as poor feeding, lethargy, vomiting, hypotonia, failure tothrive, respiratory abnormalities, apnea, bradycardia, and hypothermia.•Family history of similar illnesses, unexplained sibling deaths, or progressive neurologicaldisease.• Parental consanguinity: Most acutely presenting metabolic disorders are autosomal recessive.

questions.question: A worried mother brings her 2-year-old child with the complaints that he hasn't begunwalking or talking. On examination, there is microcephaly, fair hair, light-colored skin, andblue eyes. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given clinical manifestations point to the diagnosis of Phenylketonuria (PKU).Characteristic clinical findings in Phenylketonuria:•Mental retardation• Failure to walk or talk• Seizures•Hyperactivity•Tremor• Microcephaly•• Failure to grow•Deficiency of pigmentation (fair hair, light skin color, and blue eyes)Oculocutaneous albinism (OCA) is a group of inherited disorders characterized by a reduction orcomplete lack of melanin pigment in the skin, hair, and eyes.Its symptoms are albinism with vision problems, which include:• Strabismus• Photophobia• Nystagmus• Impaired vision or blindness• AstigmatismNeuropsychiatric manifestations are not seen.259

questions.question: Detailed ExplanationsMousy odor is characteristically seen in phenylketonuria due to excess phenylacetate (phenylketone) formed in the body.In the absence of phenylalanine hydroxylase, phenylalanine enters into alternate metabolicpathways which result in the formation of phenyl lactate, phenylacetate, andphenylacetylglutamine.Solution to Question 2:The clinical vignette describes a case of phenylketonuria. CNS damage in patients withphenylketonuria (PKU) is caused by hyperphenylalaninemia in brain tissue.High blood levels of phenylalanine saturate the transport system across the blood-brain barriercausing inhibition of the cerebral uptake of other large neutral amino acids such as tyrosine andtryptophan impairing brain protein synthesis.Microcephaly, prominent maxillae with widely spaced teeth, enamel hypoplasia, and growthretardation are other common findings in untreated children. Low bone mineral density andosteopenia have been reported in affected individuals of all ages.Excess phenylalanine is metabolized to phenyl ketones (phenylpyruvate and phenylacetate) thatare excreted in the urine. However, these metabolites have no role in the pathogenesis of CNSdamage; their presence in body fluids simply signifies the severity of the condition.247Hypotyrosinemia can be partially responsible for the signs and symptoms but the primary cause ishyperphenylalaninemia.Laboratory diagnoses of phenylketonuria include:• Guthrie's test: growth of bacillus subtilis is seen• Ferric chloride urine test: transient blue-green color• Blood phenylalanine levels: elevated.•• Enzyme studies• Genetic mutation studies• Tandem mass spectrometry: Gold standard screening method for all metabolic disorders.Solution to Question 3:Defects of either phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH) or tetrahydrobiopterin(BH4) can causehyperphenylalaninemias.PAH deficiency is diagnosed as phenylketonuria.Malignant hyperphenylalaninemias include three enzyme defects, dihydropteridinereductase, pyruvoyl tetrahydropterin synthase, and GTP cyclohydrolase which help in BH4synthesis. The deficiency of BH4 impairs three hydroxylase (phenylalanine, tyrosine, andtryptophan), and severe neurological symptoms develop because of the lack of neurotransmitters.Dihydropteroate synthase is present only in bacteria and this makes it a useful target forsulfonamide antibiotics, which compete with the PABA precursor.Solution to Question 4:A low-phenylalanine diet is the mainstay of treatment of PKU.The goal of therapy is to reduce phenylalanine levels in the plasma and brain. Becausephenylalanine is not synthesized endogenously, small amounts of phenylalanine should be addedto the diet to prevent phenylalanine deficiency. Dietary deficiency of this amino acid is manifestedby lethargy, failure to thrive, anorexia, anemia, rashes, diarrhea, and even death; moreover,tyrosine becomes an essential amino acid in this disorder and its adequate intake must beensured.Sapropterin dihydrochloride, a synthetic form of BH4, which acts as a cofactor in patients withresidual PAH activity, is approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FD

options.A: to reducephenylalanine levels in PKU.Solution to Question 5:248The clinical vignette describes a case of Hereditary tyrosinemia type 1 is caused by the deficiencyof fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase (FAAH).Elevated levels of succinylacetone in serum and urine are diagnostic for tyrosinemia type I.Liver (jaundice, acute hepatic crisis, elevated serum transaminases), kidney(hypophosphatemia),and nerve damage(extensor hypertonia of neck and trunk) are caused by metabolites of tyrosinedegradation, especially fumarylacetoacetate and succinylacetone, and is usually precipitated byminor infections.A diet low in phenylalanine and tyrosine can slow but does not halt the progression of thecondition. The treatment of choice is nitisinone (NTBC), which inhibits 4-HPPD and reduces theflux of tyrosine metabolites to FAH, thus decreasing the production of the offending compounds,fumarylacetoacetate, and succinylacetone.Tyrosine MetabolismTyrosinetransaminaseL-Tyrosinea-KGPLPGlup-Hydroxyphenylpyruvate[Q]p-HydroxyphenylpyruvatehydroxylaseCO2Homogentisate[O]HomogentisateoxidaseFe2+MaleylacetoacetateMaleylacetoacetateCis, trans isomeraseGlutathioneFumarylacetoacetateH₂OFumarateB-KetothiolasetAcetoacetaterAcetyl-CoACOASHAcetateOMARROWSolution to Question 6:Corneal ulceration is not a feature of hereditary tyrosinemia type 1. In fact, ocular manifestationsare a feature of hereditary tyrosinemia type 2 which presumably occur due to tyrosine deposition.Boiled cabbage odor may be present in tyrosinemia resulting from increased methioninemetabolites (sulfur-containing compounds).Features of hereditary tyrosinemia type 1 (hepatorenal tyrosinemia):• An acute hepatic crisis commonly heralds the onset of disease, which may progress to liverfailure, hepatocellular carcinoma, and death.•Episodes of acute peripheral neuropathy resembling porphyrias often triggered by a minorinfection, such crisis can be associated with paralytic ileus•Renal involvement, which is manifested as a Fanconi-like syndrome with hyperphosphaturia,hypophosphatemia, normal anion gap metabolic acidosis, and vitamin D-resistant rickets249The treatment of choice for HT Type 1 is nitisinone, which blocks early steps in the tyrosinedegradation pathway and limits the formation of toxic tyrosine metabolites.Note:Boiled cabbage odor can also be found in cases of Hypermethioninemia.Solution to Question 7:Palmar and plantar hyperkeratosis, herpetiform corneal ulcers, and intellectual disability are seenin hereditary tyrosinemia type 2 (Richner-Hanhart syndrome/ oculocutaneous tyrosinemia)Treatment with a diet low in tyrosine and phenylalanine aiming to achieve plasma tyrosine levels<500 μmol/L improves skin and eye manifestations.The image below shows herpetiform corneal ulcer:Solution to Question 8:Oculocutaneous tyrosinemia/Richner-Hanhart syndrome (type II) is caused by the deficiency oftyrosine aminotransferase.It is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by palmar and plantar hyperkeratosis,herpetiform corneal ulcers, and intellectual disability. Untreated patients havemarked hypertyrosinemia. In contrast to tyrosinemia type I, liver and kidney function are normal,as are serum concentrations of other amino acids and succinylacetone.250Tyrosine MetabolismTyrosinetransaminaseL-Tyrosinea-KGPLPGlup-Hydroxyphenylpyruvatep-Hydroxyphenylpyruvatehydroxylase[O]CO2HomogentisateHomogentisateoxidase[O]FOR+MaleylacetoacetateMaleylacetoacetateGlutathioneCis, trans isomeraseFumarylacetoacetateH₂OFumarateB-KetothiolaseAcetoacetaterAcetyl-CoAAcetateCOASHMARROWSolution to Question 9:Primary deficiency of 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvate dioxygenase (4-HPPD) causes hereditarytyrosinemia type 3. The diagnosis is suspected in children with sustained moderate increases inplasma levels of tyrosine (typically 350-700 μmol/L on a normal diet) and the presence of4-hydroxyphenylpyruvic acid and its metabolites 4-hydroxyphenyllactic and4-hydroxyphenylacetic acids in urine.Asymptomatic infants with 4-HPPD deficiency have been identified by neonatal screening forhypertyrosinemia. In symptomatic patients, developmental delay, seizures, intermittent ataxia,and self-injurious behavior have been reported. Liver and renal abnormalities are absent.Note:Transient tyrosinemia of the newborn is the most common acquired cause for increased plasmatyrosine levels. Seen in premature infants receiving a high protein diet and due to the immaturityof 4-HPPD enzyme. Mostly asymptomatic, but sometimes manifested by lethargy, poor feeding,and decreased motor activity. Hypertyrosinemia usually resolvesspontaneously in the first 2 months of life. Treatment includes a low protein diet and vitamin C.251Tyrosine MetabolismTyrosinetransaminaseL-Tyrosinea-KGPLPGlup-Hydroxyphenylpyruvatep-Hydroxyphenylpyruvatehydroxylase[O]CO2HomogentisateHomogentisateoxidase[O]FOR+MaleylacetoacetateMaleylacetoacetateGlutathioneCis, trans isomeraseFumarylacetoacetateH₂OFumarateB-KetothiolaseAcetoacetaterAcetyl-CoAAcetateCOASHMARROWSolution to Question 10:The clinical vignette and the characteristic swimming pool odor describe Hawkinsinuria.Hawkinsinuria is an autosomal-dominant condition caused by mutations in the gene for 4-HPPD.In infants, this disease causes severe metabolic acidosis, ketosis, failure to thrive, mildhepatomegaly, and swimming pool odor. Mental development is usually normal. Affectedindividuals excrete hawkinsin (4-hydroxyphenylpyruvic acid), and its metabolites.Treatment consists of a low-protein diet during infancy. Breastfeeding is encouraged. A trial withlarge doses of vitamin C (up to 1,000 mg/24 hour) is also recommended.Solution to Question 11:The following condition is characterized by the deficiency of homogentisic acid oxidase.The image represents ochronosis: Bluish-black pigmentation of the ear cartilage and/or sclera dueto deposits of accumulated homogentisic acid.This is characteristically seen in alkaptonuria. It is a rare autosomal-recessive disorder is causedby the deficiency of homogentisic acid oxidase. Large amounts of homogentisic acid are formed,which are excreted in urine or deposited in tissues. Clinical manifestations of alkaptonuria consistof ochronosis and arthritis in adulthood. Arthritis predominantly involves the spine, hip, andknee. Radiologically, it is characterized by intervertebral calcifications. In children, blackening ofthe urine on standing is observed; it is caused by the oxidation and polymerization ofhomogentisic acid.252Solution to Question 12:The clinical image shows the accumulation of alkapton bodies in connective tissues on the faceand urine turning brownish-black on standing are associatedwith alkaptonuria. X-ray shows calcification of intervertebral discs called ochronoticspondyloarthropathy also seen in alkaptonuria. Nitisinone can be used in the treatment ofalkaptonuria.Nitisinone, formerly known as NTBC, inhibits 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvate dioxygenase (HPPD)(early step in the tyrosine degradation pathway) and efficiently reduces homogentisic acidproduction in alkaptonuria. Treatment of arthritis is symptomatic. In presymptomatic individuals,treatment using a combination of nitisinone with phenylalanine and a tyrosine restricted diet canbe tried.The patient's urine contains elevated levels of homogentisic acid, which is oxidized to a darkpigment on standing as shown below in the image:Solution to Question 13:The clinical vignette describes a thrombotic stroke in the left MCA territory. Elevated levels ofserum homocysteine lead to a hypercoagulable state.•Homocystinuria is caused by the following:Cystathionine ẞ-Synthase deficiency: This is classic homocystinuria. The most common inbornerror of methionine metabolism.⚫ Defects in methylcobalamin formation: Methylcobalamin is the cofactor for the enzymemethionine synthase, which catalyzes the remethylation of homocysteine to methionine.• Deficiency of methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase: This enzyme reduces 5,10methylenetetrahydrofolate to form 5-methyltetrahydrofolate, which provides the methyl groupneeded for remethylation of homocysteine to methionine.253• Pyridoxine deficiency: B6 is the co-factor for the enzyme cystathionine ẞ-synthaseFolateCauses of homocystinuriaDietary proteinsTetrahydrofolate5.10-MethylenetetrahydrofolateMethylenetetrahydrofolate reductaseMethionineTransmethylationMethioninesynthaseVitamin B5-MethylenetetrahydrofolateMADimethylglycine.Betaine-homocysteinemethyltransferaseHomocysteinet +BetaineCystathioninep-synthase+Vitamin B₁LCystathionineCysteineOMARROWWMetabolic disorders which can cause stroke include:• Homocystinuria•MELAS (metabolic encephalopathy, lactic acidosis, and stroke-like episodes)• Leigh syndrome•Fabry's disease•Propionic acidemia•Glutaric aciduriaVitamin C deficiency increases the risk of hemorrhagic stroke.Solution to Question 14:The above findings support a diagnosis of homocystinuria. Short stature is not a manifestation ofhomocystinuria.Manifestations of homocystinuria:•Ectopia lentis - downward and inward subluxation (inferonasal).• Intellectual disability and psychiatric and behavioral disorders•⚫ Thromboembolic episodes like stroke and MI• Skeletal abnormalities resembling those of Marfan syndrome: They are tall and thin, (NOT short)with elongated limbs and arachnodactyly.Solution to Question 15:254Pellagra-like symptoms- photosensitive dermatitis, diarrhea, and episodic depression are seen inthe deficiency of tryptophan.Niacin is not strictly a vitamin, since it can be synthesized in the body from the essential aminoacid tryptophan; deficiency of tryptophan causes pellagra-like symptoms.Treatment with nicotinic acid or nicotinamide (50-300 mg/24 hr) and a high protein diet resultsin a favorable response in symptomatic patients with Hartnup disease.The image below shows Casal's necklace, a lesion seen around the neck which is caused due to thedeficiency of niacin or nicotinic acid.Casal's paint necklace in PellagraSolution to Question 16:The treatment of Hartnup disease is not with the supplementation of tryptophan.Hartnup disease• It is caused by a defect in the transport of monoamino-monocarboxylic (neutral) amino acids,including tryptophan, by the intestinal mucosa and renal tubules.•There is a defect in BOAT1 protein in the intestine/ renal tubules or both, which is caused by amutation in SLC6A19.•Tryptophan is an essential amino acid and a precursor for nicotinic acid (niacin) and serotonin.Decreased intestinal absorption of tryptophan in conjunction with its increased renal loss causesreduced availability of tryptophan for niacin synthesis in affected individuals.• A pellagra-like rash may develop in symptomatic patients, and some patients may haveintermittent ataxia.• Diagnosis is based on aminoaciduria and increased excretion of indole compounds detectedby Obermeyer test.• Treatment is with nicotinic acid or nicotinamide and a high-protein diet.255Solution to Question 17:In this case, hyperammonemia +, acidosis +, ketosis +. This is seen in organic aciduria.Organic acidemias most commonly present in infancy with poor feeding, vomiting, hypotonia,high anion gap metabolic acidosis, hepatomegaly, seizures.
